conversation.content: [quietly] I found the audiologist reports in the recycling bin, three of them from different clinics, all dated within the last six months.
[defensive] Those were just routine checkups for work, you know how the construction site requires annual hearing tests now with all the new safety regulations.
[gently pressing] Marcus, routine work screenings don't require follow-ups with specialists, and they definitely don't include recommendations for hearing aids marked 'urgent'.
Look, I've been managing fine without making it into some big thing, turning the TV up a bit louder isn't exactly a crisis. [dismissive exhale]
[measured] You asked me to repeat myself four times at dinner last night, and you've stopped answering your phone because you can't hear it ring anymore.
It's been getting worse for about two years now, started with just missing consonants but now whole conversations just, [sighs], disappear into noise.

[professional but caring] That progression pattern sounds like noise-induced hearing loss combined with possible early presbycusis, which is completely treatable with the right approach and equipment.
[barely audible] My dad went deaf at fifty-two, spent the last twenty years of his life isolated and angry because he was too proud to wear 'those things'.
The technology has changed dramatically even in the last five years, we're talking about devices so small they're virtually invisible, with Bluetooth connectivity and adaptive sound processing.
It's not about the technology, it's about admitting that I'm broken somehow, that I'm becoming him. [voice cracking]
You're not broken, Marcus, and you're definitely not your father because you're here having this conversation instead of shutting everyone out.
Every morning I wake up terrified that today will be the day I can't hear my alarm, or worse, that someone will need help and I won't hear them calling.
[warmly] I've fitted hundreds of devices, and the relief on people's faces when they realize they haven't lost the world of sound forever is why I do this job.
[trembling] What if it doesn't work?
[reassuring] Then we adjust, we try different models, different settings, because giving up isn't an option when there are so many solutions we haven't tried yet.
The construction guys already joke about me being the old man of the crew at thirty-eight, and now I'll be the old man with hearing aids. [bitter laugh]
[firmly] You know what's worse than wearing discrete hearing aids? Missing safety warnings on a construction site, or not hearing your sister when she calls about mom.
[quieter] Could you really fit me with something that wouldn't be obvious, something that would just let me be normal again without the whole world knowing?
I can do you one better, I'll fit you myself at the clinic after hours, no paperwork through insurance yet, just to see how it feels.
[exhales slowly] Okay, yes, let's try it, but if I hate them or if they make me feel like an invalid, I'm walking away, no arguments.
